results.title: Vector kinematics
results.creator_credit: Jack Churchill, Kevin Smith and Educational Services Incorporated
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”
Displacement, velocity and acceleration vectors are demonstrated for circular, simple harmonic and other two-dimensional motions, displayed visually on a cathode ray tube screen by an electronic computer. Francis L. Friedman discusses their relationships.

results.title: VD? See your doctor
results.creator_credit: Karl Konnery, James McCormick and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description: A straightforward presentation of the cause, symptoms and danger of venereal disease, with strong emphasis on the need to obtain early medical treatment. Although venereal disease, syphilis and gonorrhea, should be extinct in this scientific age, there is an alarming increase in their incidence.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Karl Konnery, James McCormick and Sterling Educational Films

results.title: VD: who cares?
results.creator_credit: Harry Weisbloom and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man Alive”
VD has become the second highest notifiable disease after measles, and it is spreading among the young. Some people are beginning to ask - is this epidemic the price of the permissive society? Interviews patients and doctors at the clinics to discover how an under-resourced and outdated part of the National Health Service is coping with the situation.

results.title: VD: prevent it
results.brief_description: Demonstrates that although venereal diseases are the easiest to prevent there are more cases of venereal disease than all other communicable diseases combined. The two types of venereal disease and their long-range effects if untreated are described. Regular physical examinations for the sexually active persons are recommended and the role of sexual promiscuity in spreading VD is discussed.
results.description: Demonstrates that although venereal diseases are the easiest to prevent there are more cases of venereal disease than all other communicable diseases combined. The two types of venereal disease and their long-range effects if untreated are described. Regular physical examinations for the sexually active persons are recommended and the role of sexual promiscuity in spreading VD is discussed.

results.title: VD: old bugs new problems
results.brief_description: The term sexually transmitted diseases instead of venereal diseases is now being used by health officials because there are many that are passed from one person to another through sexual contact but not always. Outlines how these diseases are contracted and describes the symptoms of Gonorrhoea, Herpes simplex, Non-gonococcal urethritis, Syphilis, Trichomoniasis, monilia, Venereal warts, Crabs and Scabies.
results.description: The term sexually transmitted diseases instead of venereal diseases is now being used by health officials because there are many that are passed from one person to another through sexual contact but not always. results.title: VD: don't take the risk
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”
Statistics show that venereal disease rates are rising, particularly among teenagers; teenagers explain how they become affected, and later describe their experiences in clinics. A lecture, sensibly frank and usefully informative in respect to symptoms, is heard and discussed by a mixed sixth form; a doctor gives further information about the spread of the disease and clinical procedure.
Follow-up to previous Granada program “The Shadow of ignorance: an inquiry”.

results.title: VD: a new focus
results.creator_credit: Noel Nosseck, American Educational Films and Directions Unlimited Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Traces the history of venereal diseases, points out the reasons why there is no vaccine for treatment and lists the symptoms of venereal disease. Emphasises the case and importance of cure in the early stages. Exposes myths surrounding venereal diseases.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Noel Nosseck, American Educational Films and Directions Unlimited Film Corporation

results.title: VD, name your contacts
results.brief_description: An examination of some typical attitudes and reactions of people who have contracted venereal disease, this film stresses the importance of revealing contacts in order to control its spread. Various young people are viewed discussing their situation with a doctor and nurse and each other showing the difficulties involved in the attempt to locate contacts who carry this highly contagious disease.

results.title: VD questions VD answers
results.creator_credit: Harry Robin, Herbert Bernard and BFA Educational Media
results.brief_description: Explains how venereal diseases are contracted, how to find out if one has the disease, how to prevent or treat the disease, and where to find help. Contains mainly animated and still photography sequences. Animation: Ralph McQuarrie, Gordon Legg.

results.title: VD every thirty seconds
results.brief_description: Every thirty seconds someone is infected with a venereal disease. it is more prevalent in the 15-25 year old group. Points out the ways in which one contracts these diseases and various treatments with emphasis on the importance of prompt medical attention in suspected cases.
